Mais quel que soit les règles spécifiques le jeu demeure une fascination, aussi bien pour les rois que pour les paysans, et presque toutes les maisons le jeu comportent quelques hommes priant désespérément pour éviter la mort et retourner le 7 qui manque pour compléter leur couleur.
TEXT.German: [TAB]In Spielhäusern finden sich die verschiedensten Würfel-, Karten- und Brettspiele. Manche beherbergen sogar Arenen für Tierkämpfe oder noch dunklere Freuden. Die Khazad sind bekannt für ihre Rattenrennen, während die Sheaim Adepten niedere Kreaturen herbeirufen lassen, die dann gegeneinander kämpfen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Aber eines habe alle Spielhäuser gemein, das beliebteste aller Spiele: Somnium. Gespielt mit Karten bei den Balseraph, auf einem Spielfeld bei den Elohim und auf groben Lederflicken beim Aschenklan, hat dieses Spiel sämtliche Schichten von Erebus in seinen Bann gezogen. Es wäre gelogen zu sagen, es würden keine Hausregeln existieren. Die Schatten gewähren Bonuspunkte für Kelchkarten, die Anhänger von Kilmorph erklären Turmkarten für immun gegen Diebstahl. Aber unabhängig von diesen Sonderregeln bleibt dieses Spiel eine wahre Faszination für Könige und für einfache Bürger und nahezu jedes Spielhaus beherbergt ein paar Spieler, die verzweifelt beten um den Tod zu verhindern und die letzten 7 Karten die ihrem Blatt fehlen zu erhalten.

TEXT.English: A Gambling House grants some happiness per 10% of the gold rate. It does tend to draw crime and increases the maintenance cost of the city. Countries that have come to depend on the happiness boost from Gambling Houses should be wary of reducing their Gold rate; doing so may start riots in their cities.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une Maison de Jeu donne du bonheur pour chaque tranche de 10% du budget consacré au revenu. Elle tend à attirer du crime et augmente le coût de maintenance de la ville. Les pays qui dépendent du bonus de bonheur des Maisons de Jeu doivent prendre garde lorsqu'ils réduisent leur revenu : faire cela peut provoquer des émeutes dans les villes.
TEXT.German: Ein Glücksspielhaus gewährt +3 Gold und +1 Zufriedenheit per 10 % Wirtschaftsrate. Allerdings lockt ein Glücksspielhaus das Verbrechen förmlich an, wodurch die Unterhaltskosten der Stadt um 10 % steigen. Zivilisationen, die sich voll auf den Zufriedenheitsbonus der Glücksspielhäuser verlassen, sollten vorsichtig mit der Reduzierung der Wirtschaftsrate sein, denn dies könnte Aufstände in den Städten auslösen.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una Casa de Apuestas proporciona felicidad por cada 10% de tasa de ingresos. Aunque tiende a aumentar el índice de criminalidad y el coste de mantenimiento de la ciudad. Los países que llegan a depender del aumento de felicidad de las Casas de Apuestas deberían preocuparse de no reducir su tasa de ingresos; dejar que ocurra podría provocar alzamientos en sus ciudades.

TEXT.English: [ICON_BULLET]Enemy units are %D1% to resist your spells
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Les unités ennemies ont une chance de %D1% de résister à vos sorts
TEXT.German: [ICON_BULLET]Feindliche Einheiten haben eine Wahrscheinlichkeit von %D1% euren Zaubersprüchen zu widerstehen.
TEXT.Spanish: [ICON_BULLET]Las unidades enemigas tienen un %D1% de resistir tus hechizos.

TEXT.English: [ICON_BULLET]Your units are %D1% to resist spells
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Vos unités ont une chance de %D1% de résister aux sorts
TEXT.German: [ICON_BULLET]Eure Einheiten haben eine Wahrscheinlickeit von %D1% Zaubersprüchen zu widerstehen.
TEXT.Spanish: [ICON_BULLET]Tus unidades tienen un %D1% de resistir hechizos.

TEXT.English: Gorilla Cage
TEXT.German: Gorillakäfig

TEXT.English: Governor's Manor
TEXT.German: Gruft des Grafen
TEXT.Spanish: Mansión del Gobernador

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Governor's Manor is the Calabim version of the Courthouse. It doesn't reduce maintenance as much as a typical courthouse but it reduces war weariness and provides +1 production for every unhappy citizen in the city.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le Manoir du Gouverneur est la version Calabim du tribunal. Il ne réduit pas le coût de maintenance comme un tribunal typique mais il réduit la Lassitude de Guerre et fournit +1 de production pour chaque citoyen malheureux dans la ville.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Gruft des Grafen ist die Calabim version des Gerichtes. Sie reduziert nicht den Stadtunterhalt wie ein normales Gericht aber es reduziert die Lustlosigkeit und liefert +1 Produktion für jeden unzufriedenen Bürger in der Stadt.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La Mansión del Gobernador es la versión Calabim del tribunal. No reduce los costes de mantenimiento típicos del tribunal pero reduce el hastío bélico y proporciona +1 de producción por cada ciudadano infeliz en la ciudad.

TEXT.English: Grand Menagerie
TEXT.German: Große Menagerie

TEXT.English: The library's majesty would be a thing of legend. Sebill's view from the fifth floor spanned from the northern slums out to Nubia's western wall and beyond that to where the countryside was trampled underfoot by mountains. Moving a crate of books, new acquisitions from the latest campaigns, she broke her gaze from the window. She was at odds with herself; technically, she'd achieved her goal and become a chief librarian at the world's greatest library. It was what she had promised her childhood friends she'd do, then they in turn would dream up something they thought was even more fantastic. Yet here she was. Slaving. Forced into her wishes' fulfillment by ravenous men under a new moon.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Her town was alight with burning houses as she woke to the screams. She shook her husband awake, scrambled for her weapon, and used it on the first blood-drenched man who burst into the bedroom. His comrades behind him overpowered her. All she could remember feeling at that moment was insult at the fact that they showed no desire to kill her. Instead, one man constrained her on the bed while they dragged her husband outside. She shrieked and swung her fists, until an attacker brought a torch into the room. In the light the men saw the bedroom and its bookshelf-lined walls. Their faces flushed with joy and they shouted congratulations to each other. That was when they knocked her unconscious.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]...there's no noise what's going on? I'm deaf no I'm dead oh good there's noise the chains oh damn me the chains. How dare they keep me down here what did they do to her the next time one of them comes down here I'll wrap these chains around him... Where is everybody I'm alone I'm alone they'll never come for me I'll die here what have they done with her I'll starve here if my heart doesn't explode first I just want to tear them to pieces! Can't stop shaking the walls are too noisy I can't hear myself how can I... Huh? They're coming those are footsteps I'll kill them and I'll get out and find her oh I'll never see her again... One footsteps two feet could it be her they don't sound hard... oh my angel what if it's her she's come to kill me oh my angel it is her![\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill hadn't seen her husband since. And now there she was, the woman she'd always wanted to be. Only the library wasn't what she'd hoped for. It was supposed to be a paragon of learning, open to all, with a collection spanning history and all of Erebus. This was a perversion, a library of spoils, built on the sudden whim of that monstrous queen Alexis to actually know something about the people she and her brother were slaughtering. And she'd let Flauros build it! It was a wonder he had any slaves left over to clean up the blood of those who built it. Sebill was horrified to hear that Alexis had been the one to finally build Erebus's greatest library, now known as the Library of Alexis. Sebill never wanted anything to do with it, but now she was its chief archivist. It was more of a wound than a title. Still, she had books. She passed the time by imagining that the library had been built by someone else: perhaps in the Kuriotate lands it would be a bridge across race and politics; in Amurite lands its knowledge would be treated with proper respect.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Books, protected by sturdy leather covers, were durable and could last ages if properly cared for. But books in Erebus were only as permanent as societies allowed. Warring nations expunged conquered peoples' libraries with the rest of their culture. The Age of Ice preserved the previous ages' treasures well, as long as firewood was more plentiful than books. The real damage came with the destruction of literate societies who knew the value of old histories and treatises. Still, Sebill thought, maybe Alexis's collection will serve some good in the long run. Perhaps Sebill's dreams were not totally lost. Spending her days cataloging family histories, journals, folktales, scientific works, philosophies, and everything else brought in from homes and palace libraries gave her faith that one day this could be shared with the world.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She unloaded the books onto the table-They were her books. She stared at them, telling herself that this was inevitable, and yet she was holding the books that belonged to her and her former neighbors. She tried to detach herself, but opening the covers felt like tearing new flesh off wounds. "Is this the last I'll ever see of my life?" she despaired. One book confirmed that it would be: a ledger, a report of the raid on her town.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]it's her it's her she came for me she sees me she'll kill me I have to kill her I'm scared I hate her I hate those men that's a sharp knife I'm going to die I should die I'm worthless I'm afraid hate hate them her skin cuts so fine[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Come on you. Drink up."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]blood! she's bleeding I can taste it already these chains hurt I want her to notice me let me go I must taste her fingers the cut is so sharp I can feel the cut on my tongue I'm okay I'll be okay she loves me I'm home I'm hers her hand is so soft it could tear me to pieces I want her to she can have me all in little bits she'll protect me my angel my angel I'll climb under her shadow her dress I'll be engulfed in her darkness her peaceful darkness she'll hold me and I'll be okay I'll be hers I'll be nothing in her abyss she loves me she will always protect me...[\BOLD][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sneaking out was unnecessary. Sebill doubted it was because they trusted her; perhaps they were certain they could find her if she ran off. The masters ignored other slaves, but had to address her because of the role they gave her. Eye contact was rare, but they had an odd way of acknowledging her presence by letting her know they were smelling her. Tonight she was betting they wouldn't find her quickly enough.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The ledger had listed the spoils, the "acquisitions." House #6 Contents. Books: 156. Woman: Educated: For especial use, she read. Man: Drunk, superior physical condition: For conscription in Red Barracks. Weapons only other items of value. She knew of the so-called "Red Barracks." Other librarians spoke fearfully, sorrowfully, of their loved ones sent there.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]She agonized during the following nights. After her life had been destroyed her only possible comfort was having all the world's books and time enough at last to read. Now that had become her hell. The only truth she wanted was outside the library. She had to find the Red Barracks.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]And she did. She was ushered right in through the front doors the moment she was spotted sneaking underneath a window. She protested, feigned ignorance, fought, but was pulled before a woman wrapping her hand in a bandage. Sebill froze; her. Alexis looked at Sebill with a sneer.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Mistress, we found her snooping. She looks like-"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"I don't care what she is. Come. Bring her." She turned and walked with her saturating, scarlet-bandaged hand at her side.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Bring her in here."[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill was thrown to the floor in a small, windowless room. The light from the room outside shone past her, and onto a man chained to the wall. Sebill bounced to her feet, but was stunned when she saw him.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain! Oh!" she shouted and ran to him. He stared at her without recognition and his lips trembled with senseless mutterings. Alexis entered the room and watched with contempt as Sebill tried to get Ain to look at her. Ain was transfixed by Alexis. Suddenly a look of eagerness showed on his face and he noticed Sebill for the first time.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]"Ain! It's me, dear!" She shook Ain and rubbed his cheeks in growing hysteria. Her eyes widened in both fear and hope when Ain looked at her. In him she saw savagery mixed with his eagerness to please. Four eyes with four different emotions looked at each other across the chasm of their broken lives. Ain then looked to Alexis, who remained still and observant in the doorway. She was glad-tonight she had something interesting to give the new recruit. She was losing interest in tossing unsatisfactory guards to these things.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Sebill, nearly sobbing, tried futilely to find her husband in this man. Ain, however, flourished in the queen's attention. Sebill was too confused to react when Ain grabbed her throat and throttled her. He found little resistance from her body as Alexis's blood burned inside him. His wife's essence slipped away and Ain looked to his queen for affirmation.
TEXT.French: La majesté de la bibliothèque serait digne de légendes. La vue de Sebill depuis le cinquième étage allait des bidonvilles du nord jusqu'au mur occidental de Nubia et au-delà jusqu'à là où la campagne était foulé aux pieds par les montagnes. Déplaçant une caisse de livres, de nouvelles acquisitions des dernières campagnes, elle détacha son regard de la fenêtre. Elle était en contradiction avec elle-même; techniquement, elle avait atteint son objectif et était devenue la bibliothécaire en chef de la plus grande bibliothèque du monde. C'était ce qu'elle avait promis qu'elle ferait à ses amis d'enfance, et à leur tour, ils imagineraient quelque chose qu'ils croyaient être encore plus fantastique. Pourtant, elle en était là. Asservie. Contrainte à l'accomplissement de ses désirs par des hommes féroces sous une nouvelle lune. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Sa ville était illuminée par des maisons qui brûlent lorsqu'elle se réveilla au son des cris. Elle secoua son mari pour le réveiller, se précipita vers son arme, et l'utilisa sur le premier homme ensanglanté qui fit irruption dans la chambre. Ses camarades derrière lui la maîtrisèrent. Tout ce qu'elle pouvait se rappeler ressentir à ce moment était l'insulte au fait qu'ils n'ont pas cherché à la tuer. Au lieu de cela, un homme l'immobilisa sur son lit pendant qu'ils traînèrent son mari dehors. Elle poussa un cri et balança ses poings, jusqu'à ce qu'un des attaquant apporte une torche dans la pièce. À la lumière les hommes virent la chambre et ses murs bordés d'étagères de livres. Leurs visages s'emplirent de joie et ils se crièrent des félicitations les uns aux autres. C'est alors qu'ils la rendirent inconsciente. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] [BOLD]... il n'y a pas de bruit , que se passe-t-il ? Je suis sourd , non , je suis mort , oh, bien, du bruit, les chaînes , ces satanées chaînes. Comment osent-ils me garder ici , que lui ont-ils fait , la prochaine fois que l'un d'eux vient ici, je vais serrer ces chaînes autour de lui... Où est tout le monde , je suis seul , je suis seul , ils ne viennent jamais pour moi, je vais mourir ici , que lui ont-ils fait , je vais mourir de faim ici si mon cour n'explose pas d'abord , je veux juste les mettre en pièces! Je n'arrête pas de trembler , les murs sont trop bruyants, je ne peux pas m'entendre , comment puis-je... Hein? Ils viennent , ce sont des bruits de pas , je vais les tuer et je vais sortir et la retrouver , oh je la reverrai jamais... Un bruit de pas, deux pieds , serait-ce-t-elle , ils ne sonnent pas durs... oh mon ange et si c'était elle , elle est venue me tuer , oh mon ange , c'est elle! [\ BOLD] [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Sebill n'avait pas vu son mari depuis. Et maintenant elle en était là, la femme qu'elle avait toujours voulu être. Seulement la bibliothèque n'était pas ce qu'elle avait espéré. Elle était censée être un parangon de l'apprentissage, ouverte à tous, avec une collection couvrant l'Histoire et tout Erebus. Ceci était une perversion, une bibliothèque de rapines, construite sur le coup de tête de cette monstrueuse reine Alexis de savoir quelque chose sur les gens qu'elle et son frère étaient en train d'abattre. Et elle avait laissé Flauros la construire! C'était un miracle qu'il y ait eu des esclaves survivant pour nettoyer le sang de ceux qui l'ont construite. Sebill a été horrifié d'apprendre qu'Alexis avait été celui qui construisit enfin la plus grande bibliothèque d'Erebus, maintenant connue comme la Bibliothèque d'Alexis. Sebill ne voulais ne jamais rien avoir à faire avec elle, mais maintenant elle était son archiviste en chef. C'était plus une blessure qu'un titre. Pourtant, elle avait des livres. Elle passait le temps en imaginant que la bibliothèque avait été construit par quelqu'un d'autre : peut-être dans les terres Kuriotate ce serait un pont entre les races et entre les politiques ; dans les terres Amurite ses connaissances serait traité avec respect. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Les livres, protégés par des couvertures en cuir solide, étaient durables et pouvaient durer des âges s'ils étaient bien entretenus. Mais en Erebus les livres étaient seulement aussi permanents que les sociétés ne l'autorisaient. Les nations belligérantes rasaient les bibliothèques des peuples conquis avec le reste de leur culture. L'Âge de glace avait préservé les trésors des âges précédents, enfin tant que le bois de chauffage était plus abondante que les livres. Le préjudice le plus important est venu avec la destruction des sociétés lettrées qui connaissaient la valeur de vieilles histoires et des traités. Pourtant, Sebill pensa, peut-être que la collection Alexis aura du bon sur le long terme. Peut-être les rêves de Sebill n'étaient pas totalement perdus. Passer ses journées à cataloguer des histoires familiales, des revues, des contes, des ouvrages scientifiques, des philosophies, et tout ce qui arrivait de bibliothèques de maisons ou de palais lui donnait foi qu'un jour cela pourrait être partagé avec le monde. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Elle déchargea les livres sur la table - Ils étaient ses livres. Elle les contempla, se disant que c'était inévitable, et pourtant elle avait dans ses mains les livres qui lui appartenaient, à elle et à ses anciens voisins. Elle essaya de s'en détacher, mais chaque ouverture d'une couverture lui semblait être une nouvelle déchirure faite dans une plaie ouverte. "Est-ce les dernières choses que je verrai de mon ancienne vie? " elle avait désespéré. Un livre lui confirmé que ce serait ainsi. Un grand livre, un rapport sur le raid de sa ville [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] [BOLD] c'est elle , c'est elle , elle est venue pour moi , elle me voit , elle va me tuer , je dois la tuer , j'ai peur , je la déteste , je déteste ces types , c'est un couteau aiguisé , je vais mourir , je dois mourir , je ne vaux rien , j'ai peur , haine , haine , je les déteste , sa peau se coupe si bien[\BOLD] [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] "Allez. Bois. " [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] [BOLD] du sang! elle saigne , je peux le sentir déjà , ces chaînes font mal , je veux qu'elle me remarque , laissez-moi partir , je dois goûter ses doigts , la coupure est si belle , je peux sentir la coupure sous ma langue , je vais bien , je vais aller bien , elle m'aime , je suis à la maison , je suis à elle , sa main est si douce qu'elle pourrait me déchirer en petit morceaux , je veux qu'elle le fasse , elle peut m'avoir , en tout petits morceaux , elle me protégera , mon ange , mon ange , je vais grimper sous son ombre , sa robe , je vais être englouti dans son obscurité , sa paisible obscurité , elle va me tenir et je serai bien , je vais être à elle , je ne serai plus rien dans son abîme elle m'aime , elle me protégera toujours... [\ BOLD] [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Se faufiler pour sortir n'était pas nécessaire. Sebill doutait que c'était parce qu'ils lui faisaient confiance, peut-être qu'ils étaient certains qu'ils pourraient la retrouver si elle s'enfuyait. Les maîtres ignoraient les autres esclaves, mais devaient lui adresser la parole en raison du rôle qu'ils lui avaient donné. Les contacts visuels étaient rares, mais ils avaient une manière curieuse de remarquer sa présence en lui faisant savoir qu'ils l'avaient sentie. Ce soir, elle pariait qu'ils ne pourraient pas la trouver assez rapidement. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Le livre avait énuméré le butin, les « acquisitions ». Maison N °6 contenu. Livres: 156. Femme : Éduquée: Pour une utilisation exceptionnelle, elle lu. Homme: ivre, condition physique supérieure : Conscription à la Caserne Rouge. Armes comme seuls autres objets de valeur. Elle avait entendu parler de la soi-disant « Caserne Rouge. " D'autres bibliothécaires parlaient avec crainte, tristesse, de leurs proches envoyés là-bas. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Elle a agonisé pendant les nuits suivantes. Après que sa vie lui ait été détruite, son seul confort était d'avoir tous les livres du monde et tout enfin assez de temps pour les lire. Maintenant c'était devenu son enfer. La seule vérité qu'elle voulait connaître était en hors de la bibliothèque. Elle devait trouver la Caserne Rouge. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Et elle l'avait fait. Elle a été menée au travers des portes principales dès qu'elle eut été repérée en train de se faufiler sous une fenêtre. Elle avait protesté, feint l'ignorance, s'était débattue, mais avait été trainée devant que une femme qui enveloppait sa main dans un bandage. Sebill se figea; ELLE. Alexis regarda Sebill avec un ricanement. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] "Maîtresse, nous l'avons trouvé en train d'espionner. Elle ressemble." [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] "Je me fiche de ce qu'elle est. Venez. Amenez-la. " Elle se retourna et sortit, elle et sa main bandée d'un rouge saturé. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] "Amenez-la ici. " [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Sebill fut jetée à terre dans une petite pièce sans fenêtre. La lumière de la salle en dehors brillait devant elle et sur un homme enchaîné au mur. Sebill bondi sur ses pieds, mais fut stupéfaite quand elle le vit. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] "Ain ! Oh !" elle cria et couru vers lui. Il la regarda sans la reconnaître et ses lèvres tremblaient de murmures insensés. Alexis entra dans la chambre et regarda avec mépris comme Sebill essayait de faire qu'Ain la regarde. Ain était hypnotisé par Alexis. Soudain, un regard plein d'empressement se montré sur son visage et il remarqua Sebill pour la première fois. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] "Ain ! C'est moi, mon cheri ! " Elle secouait Ain et frottait ses joues avec une hystérie croissante. Elle écarquilla les yeux avec crainte et espoir quand Ain la regarda. En lui, elle vit de la sauvagerie mélangé avec son envie de plaire. Quatre yeux avec quatre émotions différentes se croisèrent à travers l'abîme de leurs vies brisées. Puis Ain regarda Alexis, qui restait attentif à la porte. Elle était contente - ce soir, elle avait quelque chose d'intéressant à donner à la nouvelle recrue. Elle perdait tout intérêt à lancer quelques gardes peu satisfaisants à ces choses. [NEWLINE] [NEWLINE] Sebill, presque sanglotante, essaya en vain de retrouver son mari dans cet homme. Ain, cependant, s'épanouissant sous l'attention de la reine. Sebill était trop confuse pour réagir quand Ain saisit sa gorge et l'étrangla. Son corps ne lui opposa que peu de résistance comme le sang d'Alexis brûlait à l'intérieur de lui. L'essence de sa femme glissa au loin et Ain regarda sa reine en quête d'approbation.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Pharos was a marble watchtower and lighthouse estimated to be 300 feet high, the primary function of the lighthouse was to guide approaching ships to the harbor on an otherwise unmarked coast. Some civilizations burned fires on the top of the tower and some used mirrors to reflect sunlight. Since ships rarely sailed along coasts at night, there was little need for the lighthouse after dark.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Pharos était une tour de guet et un phare en marbre d'une hauteur estimée à 90 mètres, la fonction principale du phare était de guider les navires en approche vers le port au long du côte sans autre point de repère. Certaines civilisations faisaient brûler des feux au sommet de la tour et d'autres utilisaient des miroirs pour réfléchir la lumière du soleil. Comme les bateaux naviguaient rarement de nuit le long des côtes, il y avait rarement besoin des phares après la tombée de la nuit.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Pharos war ein marmorner Aussichts- und Leuchtturm, schätzungsweise 100 m hoch. Seine Hauptfunktion bestand darin, an einer Küste ohne andere markante Orientierungspunkte Schiffe sicher in den Hafen zu führen. Einige Zivilisationen unterhielten ein Feuer in der Turmspitze, andere benutzten Spiegel, um das Sonnenlicht zu reflektieren. Da sich Schiffe normalerweise nachts nicht in die Nähe der Küsten wagten, bestand kaum Notwendigkeit für einen Leuchtturm nach Einbruch der Dunkelheit.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El Gran Faro fue una inestimable torre de vigilancia y un faro que se estima tenía 90 metros de altura. Su función principal era guiar a los barcos cercanos al puerto por una costa que estaría de lo contrario sin marcar. Algunas civilizaciones hacían hogueras en lo alto de la torre y algunas otras reflejaban la luz del sol con espejos. Normalmente los barcos no navegaban por las costas por la noche, así que había poca necesidad de un faro de noche.

TEXT.English: Grove
TEXT.German: Hain

TEXT.English: Guild of Hammers
TEXT.German: Hallen der Architektur

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Guild of Hammers is a beautiful and ornate structure, built of stone and marble, and topped by a golden dome measuring over 100 feet in diameter. An extremely difficult engineering challenge, the dome has collapsed several times during its existence. Four graceful towers stand at the corners of the building. The interior of the building is a marvelous space of columns and arches extending up to the dome, which appears almost to float atop the building. The interior is sheathed in colored marble and golden mosaics depicting legendary scenes and images of kings.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La Guilde des Marteaux est une belle structure décorée, faite de pierre et de marbre, et surmonté d'une coupole dorée mesurant plus de 30 mètres de diamètre. Un défi technique extrêmement compliqué, le dôme s'est effondré plusieurs fois au cours de son existence. Quatre tours gracieuses forment les coins de l'édifice. L'intérieur du bâtiment est un merveilleux espace de colonnes et d'arches s'étendant jusqu'à atteindre la coupole, qui semble presque flotter en haut du bâtiment. L'intérieur est couvert de marbre coloré et de mosaïques dorées illustrant des scènes et des images de rois légendaires.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Hallen der Architektur sind eine herrliche, reich geschmückte Anlage aus Stein und Marmor. Sie wird von einer goldenen Kuppel gekrönt, die über 30 m Durchmesser hat  eine sehr schwierige Konstruktion für die Ingenieure. Schon mehrfach ist die Kuppel in sich zusammengebrochen. Vier anmutige Türme zieren die Ecken des Gebäudes. Das Innere besteht aus einer phantastischen Halle mit Säulen und Bögen, die sich bis in die wie schwerelos darüber schwebende Kuppel hinauf schwingen. Die Wände sind mit farbigem Marmor ausgekleidet und goldene Mosaike zeigen legendäre Szenen und Bilder der Könige.

TEXT.English: Guild of the Nine
TEXT.German: Gilde der Neun

TEXT.English: [ICON_BULLET]Allows the player to hire [LINK=literal]Mercenary[\LINK] units.
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Authorise le joueur à embaucher des unités de [LINK=literal]Mercenary[\LINK].
TEXT.German: [ICON_BULLET]erlaubt dem Spieler [LINK=literal]Mercenary[\LINK] anzuheuern.
TEXT.Spanish: [ICON_BULLET]Permite al jugador reclutar [LINK=Mercenary]Mercenarios[\LINK].

TEXT.English: Hall of Kings
TEXT.German: Ruhmeshalle der Könige

TEXT.English: [TAB]The beauty of the Hall of Kings has long served as a testament to the mixture of strong religious beliefs and the love of art shared by the people of the Age of Rebirth. Few visitors to the Hall of Kings have failed to be moved by the artist's dedication to his subject, or his feeling for the nature of human struggle, suffering, and spiritual triumph.
TEXT.French: La beauté de la Galerie des Rois a servi durant longtemps de testament du mélange de fortes convictions religieuses et d'amour de l'art partagé par les peuples de l'Âge de Renaissance. Peu de visiteurs de la Galerie des Rois n'ont été transportés par le dévouement de l'artiste envers son sujet, ou par son rapport à la nature de la lutte humaine, de la souffrance et du triomphe spirituel.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Schönheit der Ruhmeshalle der Könige gilt seit langem als Beweis für die Verbindung von starker Religiosität und Kunstsinnigkeit bei den Menschen des Zeitalters der Wiedergeburt. Nur wenige Besucher der Ruhmeshalle der Könige konnten sich der Hingabe des Künstlers an seine Darstellungen, bzw. seinem Gespür für die menschlichen Anstrengungen, das Leiden und den Triumph des Geistes entziehen.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La belleza del Salón de los Reyes ha servido durante mucho como testamento de la combinación entre la fuerte convicción religiosa y el amor al arte de las gentes de la Edad del Renacimiento. Son pocos los visitantes del Salón de los Reyes los que no han sido atrapados por la dedicación del artista a su obra, o su sentimiento de la naturaleza de la fuerza, el sufrimiento y el triunfo espiritual del ser humano.

TEXT.English: Hall of Mirrors
TEXT.German: Halle der Spiegel

TEXT.English: At the beginning of each turn, the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Hall of Mirrors[COLOR_REVERT] will create an Illusionary summons that is a copy of a random enemy unit who is within one tile of the city.
TEXT.French: Au début de chaque tour, la[COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Galerie des Mirrors[COLOR_REVERT] invoque une Illusion qui est la copie conforme d'une unité ennemie aléatoire parmis celles présentes dans un rayon d'une case de la citée.
TEXT.Spanish: Al comienzo de cada turno, la [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Sala de los Espejos[COLOR_REVERT] creará una invocación Ilusoria que es una copia de un enemigo aleatorio que esté a una casilla de la ciudad.

TEXT.English: Sea Haven
TEXT.German: Seehafen

TEXT.English: What'cha doin' Otis?[NEWLINE][TAB]"Sittin' in the mornin' sun."[NEWLINE]"Got any plans for the day?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"I'll be sittin' when the evenin' come."[NEWLINE]"Why is that, what's the appeal?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Watching the ships roll in."[NEWLINE]"But what about after that's done?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Then I watch 'em roll out again."[NEWLINE]"You must really like watching ships."[NEWLINE][TAB]"I like not working today."[NEWLINE]"What about when the ships are docked?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Then I watch the tide roll away."[NEWLINE]"Shouldn't you be getting to work?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"If you check back tomorrow I may."[NEWLINE]"The foreman won't be happy to hear..."[NEWLINE][TAB]"What do you think he'll say?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][song repeats][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Lanun rowing and drinking song, usually sung by two groups with one group singing the Otis part and the other the Urlman part.
TEXT.French: "Tu fais quoi Otis ?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Je r'garde le soleil s'lever."[NEWLINE]"T'as des plans pour aujourd'hui ?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Je serai encore assis là quand viendra l'soir."[NEWLINE]"Pourquoi ça, quel est l'interêt?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Regarder les bâteaux entrer"[NEWLINE]"Mais après ça?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Ensuite j'les r'garde resortir"[NEWLINE]"Tu dois vraiment aimer regarder les bâteaux."[NEWLINE][TAB]"J'aime ne pas travailler aujourd'hui"[NEWLINE]"Et quand les bâteaux sont à quai ?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Alors je r'garde la marée descendre"[NEWLINE]"Ne devrais-tu pas aller travailler ?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Si tu repasses demain j'y serai peut-être."[NEWLINE]"Le chef ne va pas être content..."[NEWLINE][TAB]"Qu'est ce que tu crois qu'il va dire ?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE](la chanson se répète)[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Chanson à boire de marins Lanun, généralement chantée par deux groupes, l'un chantant la partie d'Otis et l'autre celle d'Urlman.
TEXT.German: "Sag Otis was machste hier?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Sitze in der Sonne."[NEWLINE]"Haste heute schon was vor?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Bleibe bis zum Abend."[NEWLINE]"Warum denn das, was gibt's zu sehn?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Schau zu wie Schiffe kommen."[NEWLINE]"Und wenn du damit fertig bist?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Schau zu wie Schiffe wieder fahrn."[NEWLINE]"Scheinst gar gerne zu zuschaun"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Mag heut nicht zur Arbeit gehn"[NEWLINE]"Doch wenn die Schiffe all im Dock?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Schau ich halt den Wellen zu"[NEWLINE]"Solltest nicht zur Arbeit gehen?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Morgen vielleicht, nu lass ma sein"[NEWLINE]"Der Vorarbeiter wird's nicht gern sehn..."[NEWLINE][TAB]"Und was glaubst du sagt er dann?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][beginnt von vorne][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Lanunisches Ruder- und Trinklied, normalerweise von zwei Gruppen gesungen, wobei eine Gruppe Otis und die andere den Urlmann singt.
TEXT.Spanish: ¿Qué tás haciendo Otis?[NEWLINE][TAB]"Sentao, bajo el sol de la mañana aquí."[NEWLINE]"¿Algún plan pa' hoy?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Seguiré sentao cuando llegue la tarde."[NEWLINE]"¿Pero por qué, pa' qué?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Pa' ver los barcos entrar"[NEWLINE]"¿Pero después de 'so qué?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Después los veré irse otra vé'"[NEWLINE]"Que te gustan los barcos o qué."[NEWLINE][TAB]"Lo que me gusta es no trabajar hoy"[NEWLINE]"¿Y qué pasa cuando los barcos están amarrados?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Pue' que miraré el ir y venir de la tripulación"[NEWLINE]"¿No deberías ponerte a trabajá?"[NEWLINE][TAB]"Si me lo vuelves a preguntar mañana, quizá."[NEWLINE]"El jefe no estará contento de oir..."[NEWLINE][TAB]"¿Qué va a decir?"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][se repite la canción][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Canción de remo Lanun, cantada por cada grupo de remeros.

TEXT.English: Herbalist
TEXT.German: Kräuterkundige

TEXT.English: [TAB]Be they from the Age of Ice, the Age of Magic, or all the way back to the Age of Dragons, these stories are about men that became legends. They encourage all that hear them, and make their hearers strive to be more than they currently are.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Qu'elles datent de l'Age de Glace, de l'Age de la Magie ou encore plus loin de l'Age des Dragons, ces histoires parlent d'hommes qui sont devenus des légendes. Elles encouragent ceux qui les écoutent et les motive à se surpasser.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Seien sie aus dem Zeitalter des Eises, dem Zeitalter der Magie, oder gar aus dem Zeitalter der Drachen, diese Geschichten handeln von Männern, die zu Legenden geworden sind. Sie ermutigen alle, die sie hören, und regen die Hörer an, danach zu eifern, mehr zu sein als im Augenblick.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Ya sean de la Edad de Hielo, la Edad de la Magia, o de tiempo atrás hasta la Edad de los Dragones, estas historias cuentan como unos hombres o mujeres se convirtieron en leyenda. Llenan de valentía a todo aquel que las lea, y hace que sus oyentes aspiren a ser algo más grande de lo que ya son.

TEXT.English: The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Heroic Epic[COLOR_REVERT] doubles its city's production when creating military units. This is useful if you expect to do a lot of fighting.
TEXT.French: [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]L'Epopée Héroïque[COLOR_REVERT] double la production d'unités militaires dans cette ville. C'est utile si vous vous attendez à beaucoup de combat. Elle augmente aussi la probabilité que la ville génère un [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Commandant Illustre[COLOR_REVERT].
TEXT.German: Der [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Heldenepos[COLOR_REVERT] verdoppelt die Produktion von Militäreinheiten in der Stadt. Dies ist überaus nützlich, wenn man viele Schlachten schlägt. Außerdem erhöht das Gebäude die Wahrscheinlichkeit für einen [COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Genialen Feldherrn[COLOR_REVERT]
TEXT.Spanish: La [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Epopeya Heróica[COLOR_REVERT] dobla la producción de unidades militares de una ciudad. Esto es muy útil si se espera muchos combates.

TEXT.English: Heron Throne
TEXT.German: Herons Thron

TEXT.English: [ICON_BULLET]Makes all your units invisible while they are within your borders and not in a city.
TEXT.French: [ICON_BULLET]Rend toutes vos unités invisible tant qu'elle sont à l'interieur de vos frontières, hors d'une citée.
TEXT.German: [ICON_BULLET]Alle deine Einheiten sind unsichtbar solange sie sich innerhalb eurer Kulturgrenzen und nicht in einer Stadt aufhalten.
TEXT.Spanish: [ICON_BULLET]Hace a todas tus unidades invisibles mientras que estén dentro de tus fronteras y no estén en una ciudad.

TEXT.English: Hope
TEXT.German: Hoffnung

TEXT.English: [TAB]Created by the Hope spell. Raises the cultural output of the city. Lasts until the caster leaves the city.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Créé par le sort Espoir. Augmente la production culturelle de la ville. Dure jusqu'à ce que le lanceur de sort quitte la ville.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Erschaffen durch den Zauber Hoffnung. Erhöht den Kulturausstoß der Stadt. Hält an, bis der Zauberer die Stadt verlässt.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Creada por el conjuro Esperanza. Aumenta la cultura de la ciudad. Permanecerá hasta que el lanzador deje la ciudad.

TEXT.English: Human Cage
TEXT.German: Menschenkäfig

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Human Cage can only be created by the Balseraph civilization in a city with a Freak Show. A Slave must be sacrificed to create one.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La Cage à Humain peut seulement être créée par la civilisation Balseraph dans une ville ayant une Foire aux Monstres. Un Esclave doit être sacrifié pour la créer.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Menschenkäfig kann nur von den Balseraph in einer Stadt mit einer Abnormitätenschau gebaut werden. Ein Menschensklave muss dafür geopfert werden.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La Jaula de Humanos sólo puede fabricarla la civilización Balseraph en una ciudad con un Espectáculo Monstruoso. Debe sacrificarse un Esclavo Humano para crear una.

TEXT.English: Hunting Lodge
TEXT.German: Jagdhaus

TEXT.English: [TAB]"I fletch arrows, as hunters feast on game. I sharpen blades as the rangers trades the secrets of the wilds, of topography and the enemy's movements. I brew poison as the assassins discuss their cleanest kills with grim smiles. Why do I toil away, you ask, serving the brave brothers and deadly sisters of the lodge, not to mention their pets? Because one day, one day soon, I will be one of them." -Locke Thorne, scout
TEXT.French: "J'empenne des flèches, tandis que les chasseurs festoient de gibier. J'aiguise les lames alors que les forestiers s'échangent les secrets des contrées sauvages, de la topographie et des mouvements ennemis. Je prépare le poison tandis que les assassins discutent de leur plus discrets meurtres avec des sourires menaçants. Pourquoi peine-je au loin, me demandez-vous, servant les braves frères et les mortelles soeurs du pavillon, sans parler de leurs animaux ? Parce qu'un jour, un jour proche, je serai l'un des leurs." - Locke Thorne, Eclaireur
TEXT.German: [TAB]"Ich befedere die Pfeile, während die Jäger dem Wild nachstellen. Ich schärfe die Klingen, während die Waldläufer den Geheimnissen der Wildtiere, des Geländes und den Bewegungen des Feindes nachspüren. Ich mische Gifte, während die Meuchelmörder mit grimmigem Grinsen von ihren makellosesten Morden erzählen. Warum ich mir diese Mühe mache, fragst du, den mutigen Brüder und tödlichen Schwestern hier zu dienen, ganz zu schweigen von ihren Tieren? Weil ich eines Tages, sehr bald sogar, einer von ihnen sein werde." - Locke Thorne, Späher
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]"Emplumo las flechas, mientras los cazadores disfrutan de sus piezas. Afilo espadas cuando los montaraces comercian los secretos de la espesura, de la topografía y los movimientos enemigos. Preparo veneno cuando los asesinos discuten sus muertes más limpias con risa amenazante. ¿Por qué trabajo como un esclavo, preguntáis, sirviendo a los valientes hermanos y mortíferas hermanas del refugio, por no mencionar sus mascotas? Porque un día, pronto, yo seré uno de ellos." - Locke Thorne, batidor

TEXT.English: Infirmary
TEXT.German: Krankenlager

TEXT.English: [TAB]I stare out the window a lot now. Outside there are children playing, laughing, running, and chasing each other. They will never know war. They will never know sacrifice, and I am grateful for that. To see the sun rise and fall, and never understand loss like mine is a beautiful and tragic thing.[PARAGRAPH:1]My nurse comes regularly to me, to tend to my leg, and to ask if my other still feels like it's there. It does sometimes. I dream that I wander through our old house, your golden hair shining in the sunlight and lightening my heart. I chase you in my dreams, through our fields in Yullda pass, and ride our horses together. I know those days are gone. I know you've found someone new, and I am happy for you. I expect her to love you as I did.[PARAGRAPH:1]Your mother visited me once, and cried for me. Tell her not to worry, there are worse here than I.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Je regarde beaucoup à la fenêtre maintenant. Dehors des enfants jouent, rient, courent et se poursuivent. Ils ne connaîtront jamais la guerre. Ils ne connaîtront jamais le sacrifice, et j'en suis reconnaissant. Voir le soleil se lever et se coucher, et ne jamais comprendre une perte comme la mienne est à la fois beau et tragique.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mon infirmière vient régulièrement me voir pour soigner ma jambe, et me demander si j'ai encore cette sensation que la seconde soit toujours là. Cela arrive parfois. Je rêve que j'erre dans notre vieille maison, que tes cheveux dorés brillent au soleil et illuminent mon coeur. Je te poursuis dans mes rêves, à travers nos champs de la passe de Yullda, et nous chevauchons tous les deux. Je sais ces jours révolus. Je sais que tu as trouvé quelqu'un d'autre, et je m'en réjouis. J'attends d'elle qu'elle t'aime comme je l'ai fait.[PARAGRAPH:1]Ta mère m'a rendu une fois visite, et a pleuré pour moi. Dis-lui de ne pas s'inquiéter, d'autres sont plus mal lotis que moi.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Oft schaue ich aus dem Fenster dieser Tage. Sehe den Kindern draußen zu, wie sie lachen, toben und Fangen spielen. Niemals werden sie den Krieg kennen lernen. Und auch nicht seine Opfer, und dafür bin ich dankbar. Aufzuwachsen und zu sterben, ohne jemals einen Verlust wie den meinen erlitten zu haben, ist ein wunderschönes, tragisches Schicksal.[PARAGRAPH:1]Meine Krankenschwester kommt regelmäßig vorbei, um sich um mein Bein zu kümmern und zu fragen, ob ich das andere immer noch spüren kann. Manchmal ja. Ich träume davon, wieder durch unser altes Haus zu gehen, wie dein goldenes Harr in der Sonne glänzt und mein Herz erhellt. Im Traum jag ich Dich wieder durch unsere Felder am Yulldapass und wir reiten zusammen aus. Ich weiß, dass diese Zeit vorbei ist. Ich weiß, dass Du jemand neues gefunden hast, und ich freue mich für Dich. Ich hoffe, dass sie Dir dieselbe Liebe schenkt, wie ich es tat.[PARAGRAPH:1]Deine Mutter hat mich neulich besucht und mich beweint. Sag ihr, dass sie sich keine Sorgen machen soll. Vielen hier geht es noch wesentlich schlimmer.
TEXT.Spanish: TAB]Me mantengo de pie delante de la ventana con frecuencia ahora. Fuera hay niños jugando, riendo, corriendo y persiguiéndose los unos a los otros. Nunca conocerán la guerra. Nunca conocerán el sacrificio, y por ello estoy agradecida. Ver el amanecer y el atardecer, y nunca entender que una pérdida como la mía es algo precioso y trágico.[PARAGRAPH:1]Mi enfermera me visita regularmente, para atender mi pierna y preguntarme si aún siento que la otra sigue ahí. A veces pasa. Sueño que vuelvo a nuestra antigua casa, con tu pelo dorado brillando al sol e iluminando mi corazón. Te persigo en mis sueños, a trevés de nuestros campos del paso de Yullda, y cabalgar nuestros caballos juntos. Se que esos días se han ido. Se que has encontrado a otra, y me alegro por tí. Espero que ella te ame tanto como yo te amé.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tu madre me visitó una vez, y lloró por mí. Dile que no se preocupe, los hay mucho peores que yo por aquí.

TEXT.English: Inn
TEXT.German: Gasthaus

TEXT.English: [TAB]The hustle and bustle of a city inn sets it apart from its countryside relative where benches have often warped to fit the posterior of its regular host. It serves much the same function, acting as a place to unwind and as a community centre, but the fiddle doesn't always stop when a new face appears.[PARAGRAPH:1]The city inn serves other, less expected functions though: it is a center for business-legitimate or not, it is a place where new contacts are made, a center for the spread of information and new, or imported, ideas. True, some of those ideas are quickly passed over with a clearer head the next morning, some of the information is "beer talk," and some of the contacts are best left forgotten, but there are few other places where an Amurite could meet a Balseraph where they are not (necessarily) swinging a sword at each other.[PARAGRAPH:1]Contacts are created, palms are greased, and the business of running a city, and even an empire, are made.[PARAGRAPH:2]Extract from a recently recovered University dissertation: "A Treatise of the City Inn: the Wheels of Empire" by Kandros Fir
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le tohu-bohu d'une auberge de ville la distingue de ses cousines paysannes où les bancs sont souvent déformés par le postérieur des hôtes réguliers. Elle sert la même fonction, agissant comme un lieu où se détendre et comme un centre de la communauté, mais le violon ne s'arrête pas toujours quand un nouveau visage apparaît [PARAGRAPHE:1]. L'auberge de ville sert d'autres fonctions, moins attendus: c'est un centre pour faires des affaires légales ou non, c'est un endroit où de nouveaux contacts sont pris, un centre de diffusion de l'information et des idées, nouvelles ou importées. Certes, certaines de ces idées sont rapidement ignorées avec une tête plus claire le lendemain matin, une partie de l'information est faite de "ragots de comptoir" et certains des contacts sont à oublier, mais il n'y a peu d'autres endroits où un Amurite pourrait rencontrer un Balseraph sans qu'ils ne sortent (nécessairement) leurs épées. [PARAGRAPHE:1] Des contacts sont pris, des paumes sont graissés, et la gestion d'une ville, ou même d'un empire y est faite.[PARAGRAPHE:2] Extrait d'une Thèse Universitaire récemment récupéré: "Traité sur l'Auberge de Ville: les Rouages de l'Empire " par Kandros Fir
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das geschäftige Treiben eines städtischen Gasthauses unterscheidet es von seinem Pendant auf dem Land, wo die Bänke sich oft schon verformt haben um sich den Hinterteilen der Stammgäste anzupassen. Es erfüllt dem selben Zweck - es ist ein Ort der Entspannung und ein Gemeindezentrum - aber die Musik verstummt nicht immer sobald ein neues Gesicht das Gasthaus betritt.[PARAGRAPH:1]Das städtische Gasthaus erfüllt auch andere, weniger erwartete Zwecke: Es ist ein Ort für Geschäfte - ob seriös oder nicht, es ist ein Ort wo neue Bekanntschaften gemacht werden und ein Umschlagplatz für Informationen und neue - oder importierte - Ideen. Wahrlich, so manche dieser Ideen überdenkt man am nächsten Morgen und mit einem klareren Kopf schnell wieder, einige dieser Informationen sind trunkenes Geschwätz und manche Bekanntschaften werden am besten gleich wieder vergessen, aber es gibt nur wenige andere Plätze an denen ein Amurit einen Balseraph treffen kann ohne sie (gleich) die Schwerter schwingen.[PARAGRAPH:1]Bekanntschaften werden gemacht, Hände werden geschüttelt und eine Stadt - oder gar ein Reich - wird am Laufen gehalten.[PARAGRAPH:2]Auszug aus einer kürzlich gefundenen Universitätsdissertation: "Eine Abhandlung über das städtische Gasthaus: Die Räder eines Reiches", Kandros Fir

TEXT.English: Inspiration
[TAB]Created by the Inspiration spell. Raises the research production of the city. Ends when the caster leaves the city.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Créé par le sort Inspiration. Augmente la production de recherche de la cité. Se termine lorsque le lanceur de sort quitte la ville.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Erschafft den Zauber Inspiration. Steigert die Wissenschaftsleistung der Stadt. Wirkung endet sobald der Zaubernde die Stadt wieder verlässt.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Creado por el conjuro Inspiración. Aumenta la investigación de la ciudad. Termina cuando el lanzador abandona la ciudad.

TEXT.English: Jeweler
TEXT.German: Edelsteinhändler

TEXT.English: [TAB]A lighthouse is a tower constructed on the shoreline, usually near a harbor or busy waterway. A powerful light sits atop the tower, making the structure visible to mariners for miles around. Lighthouses are built to mark the location of rocks and shoals or other hazards in the dead of night or midst of storms. Before their invention, any vessel sailing near the shore ran a risk of running into such hazards and sinking. Naturally, sailors preferred to sail to destinations that had a method of marking these perils, so harbors with lighthouses flourished. [PARAGRAPH:1]The original "lighthouse" was probably a bonfire lit by villagers to guide the villages fishing vessels back to harbor at night. Over time people realized that the fires could be seen much farther away if they were built atop platforms or towers. Further improvements were made as technology advanced; mirrors were built to direct the light in the desired directions and oil lamps replaced the more dangerous bonfires.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un phare est une tour construite sur le rivage, généralement près d'un port ou d'une voie navigable fréquentée. Une puissante lumière siège au sommet, rendant l'édifice visible par les marins depuis des kilomètres alentour. Les phares sont construits pour marquer la position de récifs ou de hauts-fonds ou d'autres dangers au coeur de la nuit, ou en pleine tempête. Avant leur invention, tout bateau naviguant près des côtes courrait le risque de tomber dans de tels pièges et de couler. Naturellement, les marins préféraient voguer vers des destinations qui avaient un moyen de marquer ces périls; alors les ports munis de phares prospèrerent.[PARAGRAPH:1]Le "phare" original était probablement un grand feu allumé la nuit par des villageois pour guider les bateaux de pêches sur le chemin du retour. Avec le temps, les gens réalisèrent que les feux se voyaient de plus loin lorsqu'ils étaient placés en hauteur, sur une plate-forme ou sur une tour. De nouvelles améliorations furent faites avec l'avancée de la technologie : des miroirs furent construits pour diriger la lumière dans la direction désirée et les lampes à huile remplacèrent les feux bien plus dangereux.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Leuchtturm ist ein Turm der an der Küste gebaut wird, normalerweise in der Nähe eines Hafens einer viel befahrenden Wasserstrasse. Ein mächtiges Licht sitzt oben im Turm und sorgt dafür dass Seeleute das Gebäude auch aus einer Entfernung von vielen Kilometern sehen können. Leuchtürme werden gebaut um den Ort von Felsen und Untiefen oder anderen Gefahren im Dunkeln der Nacht oder in mitten eines Sturms zu markieren. Vor der Erfindung des Radars, der Elektrizität und globaler Positionierungssysteme, ging jedes Schiff welches nahe der Küste segelte das Risiko ein, in solchen Gefahren zu manöverieren und unterzugehen. [PARAGRAPH:1] Der orginale "Leuchtturm" war wahrscheinlich ein Lagerfeuer entfacht durch Dorfbewohner um die Fischerboote sicher zum Hafen zu geleiten in der Nacht. Mit der Zeit erkannten sie dass das Feuer noch sehr viel weiter gesehen werden konnte, wenn es oben auf einer Plattform oder einem Turm brannte. Weitere Verbesserungen wurden gemacht als neue Technologien entwickelt wurden; Spiegel wurden gebaut um das Licht in die gewünschte Richtung zu senden und Öllampen ersetzten die wesentlich gefährlicheren Lagerfeuer.
TEXT.Spanish: TAB]Un faro es una torre construida en la costa, normalmente cerca de un puerto o aguas transitadas. Una luz potente se asienta en lo alto de la torre, haciendo que la estructura sea visible para los marineros a kilómetros de distancia. Los faros se levantan para marcar la localización de rocas y arrecifes u otros peligros en la peligrosa oscuridad de la noche o en medio de tormentas. Antes de la invención del radar, la electricidad y los sistemas de posicionamiento global, cualquier barco que navegara cerca de la costa corría el riesgo de acercarse a esa clase de peligros y naufragar. Naturalmente, los navegantes preferían ir a destinos que tuvieran un método para marcar estos peligros, y de esta forma los puertos con faros florecieron. [PARAGRAPH:1]El faro "original" seguramente fue una fogata colocada por aldeanos para guiar a los pesqueros de vuelta al puerto por la noche. Con el tiempo la gente se dio cuenta de que los fuegos podían verse mucho más lejos si fueran colocados en lo alto de una plataforma o torre. Se fueron añadiendo mejoras según avanzaba la tecnología; se construyeron ventanas para dirigir la luz hacia una determinada dirección y las lámparas de aceite reemplazaron a las más peligrosas hogueras o fogatas.

TEXT.English: Lion Cage
TEXT.German: Löwenkäfig

TEXT.English: [TAB]If a wild Lion is captured it can be taken to a city with a Carnival and added to the city as an attraction. This raises both the cultural and happiness effects of the Carnival.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Si un Lion sauvage est capturé, il peut être emmené dans une ville comportant un Carnaval et ajouté à la cité en tant qu'attraction. Cela augmente à la fois la culture et le bonheur du Carnaval.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Wird ein wilder Löwe gefangen, kann er in eine Stadt mit einem Jahrmarkt gebracht werden und der Stadt als Attraktion zugefügt werden. Dadurch werden beide Effekte des Jahrmarktes (Kultur und Zufriedenheit) verstärkt.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Si se captura a un león salvaje, éste puede ser llevado a una ciudad con un Carnaval y añadido a una ciudad como una atracción. Esto aumenta los efectos de la cultura y la felicidad del Carnaval.

TEXT.English: Mage Guild
TEXT.German: Magischer Zirkel

TEXT.English: [LINK=UNIT_FAWN]Chapter 1: Beltane Cycle[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=UNIT_SATYR]Chapter 2: Beltane Cycle[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=BUILDING_MONUMENT]Chapter 3: Beltane Cycle[\LINK][NEWLINE]Chapter 4: Beltane Cycle[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Although it wasn't uncommon for disciples to miss the evening bell during Beltane, and not unheard of to still be missing the next morning, it was out of character for the bookish disciple Wyren. He had been the least interested in the festival and outside of his religious obligations hadn't attended many of the games or displays that crowded the elven capital.[PARAGRAPH:1]Priest Tuathal watched the flowerbed in concern. The flowers that each bloomed during different parts of the day, arrayed in an arc in order as they bloomed. Numbers marked each section and allowed the flowerbed to function as a large living clock as it was easy to tell the time by looking at the flowers that were in bloom. It was nearly noon and Wyren was still missing.[PARAGRAPH:1]A squirrel chattered loudly above the priest, hoping he may have some treats. Tuathal scowled back, unhappy to see the animal expecting to be fed rather than gathering the food from the forest himself. But the squirrel wouldn't give up and followed the priest from tree to tree as he walked into the grove between the three temples.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tuathal quietly prayed for some guidance. He couldn't help but feel that something bad had happened to Wyren even if everything else seemed normal. Unhappy at being ignored the squirrel climbed out on the branch closest to Tuathal and then jumped from there onto the satyr statue at the center of the grove. But instead of landing gracefully on the satyr's broad arm the squirrel passed completely through the statue and landed with a confused thud on the ground.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tuathal stared in surprise at the squirrel and the statue he had just jumped through. Pulling an acorn from his pocket he scooped the squirrel up onto his shoulder and gave him the nut while studying the statue. The squirrel studied it suspiciously as well.[PARAGRAPH:1]Slowly reaching out Tuathal's hand passed effortlessly through the statue; it was only an illusion. The real statue was gone.[PARAGRAPH:2]Hemah watched as the grove filled up with priests, city watch, and mages investigating the missing statue. He wasn't worried about being noticed, as a significant crowd of curious travelers, disciples and adepts had turned up to watch what was going on.[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon, an elven man with golden hair and green eyes was leading the investigation. He wore the garb of a watch captain but it was obvious from his bearing that he was nobility as well. The captain checked out the statue himself and then after conferring with a shrugging group of mages ordered someone to get Thessa. Hemah leaned forward in interest, this was the first time he had heard her name but he suspected he already knew who she was.[PARAGRAPH:1]While he waited the captain investigated the rest of the grove, ordering people back. He found wagon tracks leading into the grove, and the heavier set leading out. They lead back out to one of the busiest roads in Evermore, where they were impossible to track. But he sent a group of soldiers down the road anyway to see what they could find. He asked another to start questioning the local wagoneers to see if anyone had stored or purchased a wagon capable of carrying a marble statue in the past few days. The day after Beltane there were hundreds of wagons in Evermore that fit that description, but the lieutenant accepted his charge and set off to perform it.[PARAGRAPH:1]Shortly afterwards a beautiful archmage entered the grove and the theorizing mages grew quiet. She talked quietly with the captain, asked a few questions to the mages, who shrugged again, and then went over and knelt down by the statue.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Is the statue of anyone in particular?" she asked.[PARAGRAPH:1]Priest Tuathal scowled but controlled himself before responding, "Surely your studies keep you too long from the temple lady Thessa. The statue is of Gower, favored son of Cernunnos, who was killed by Agares during the first Age. This statue was erected by the elves of that age in memory of him. It is one of the oldest relics in Evermore."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thieves usually aren't that interested in history and there are a thousand statues in Evermore that would have been easier to steal. Is there any reason why this one would be more valuable?"[PARAGRAPH:1]The priest cleared his throat. The eyes of everyone in the grove went to him and the squirrel on his shoulder glared back at everyone.[PARAGRAPH:1]After an awkward silence Tuathal said, "we may need to talk about that in private."[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon ordered one of his guards to have the priest taken into the temple for a more private conversation. But Thessa ignored the response, to her it was just another example of how the traditions of the Ljosalfar were keeping it from moving ahead. Taking a deep breath she closed her eyes and began to cast.[PARAGRAPH:1]If she was beautiful, she was even more beautiful while in the throes of magic. Her dark hair, unusual among the Ljosalfar, fluttered and her body strained as she channeled the power needed to cast the spell. Hemah recognized it, she would be trying to follow the link between the illusion and the one maintaining it. She was trying to find him. But just before her spell was completed Hemah released the illusion and the statue disappeared.[PARAGRAPH:1]"What happened, did you dispel it?" Devon asked.[PARAGRAPH:1]With the object of her spell gone Thessa struggled to release the magic harmlessly. Her hands glowed as if stars danced from them and then faded out.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No," Thessa answered, "I hadn't done anything yet. The caster released the spell before I could follow it back to him."[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon looked up at the assembled group of spectators, who dumbly returned his gaze. He turned to the last of his lieutenants.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Have everyone here be brought to the barracks for questioning."[PARAGRAPH:1]A few hours later Hemah was still sitting in the barracks waiting to be questioned. All of the citizens of Evermore had been first, and questioning them went relatively quickly. But they were taking their time with the travelers. Hemah had already released the spell he cast on Alazkan's amulet, he hoped it hid him for long enough. And unlike most mages he didn't keep anything magical on him. He was less concerned with the questioning then he was in making sure he got the right questioner.[PARAGRAPH:1]Fortunately Thessa was in charge of examining all the travelers and just after nightfall his name was called and he was shuffled into a small office with her. Thessa looked over the notes a soldier had collected on the group and the items they had taken from Hemah.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Are these yours?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes," Hemah answered.[PARAGRAPH:1]"What are you doing in Evermore?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"I came for the festival." Hemah said somewhat honestly.[PARAGRAPH:1]"A common answer today, do you worship Cernunnos?" Thessa asked the questions as a matter of protocol, she was more interested in looking through the items he had. She had the golden feather, mask and bag of incense laid out on the table and she was carefully examining the feather.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No, I'm not really religious. Though I do enjoy the sights of Evermore and the festival."[PARAGRAPH:1]This was the first time Thessa looked up at him, most of the people she talked to today claimed to be worshipers even if they weren't. He had a gentle face, almost soft and would be handsome if he didn't look so tired. He didn't match what she would expect from a merchant, mage or one of the many people that flocked to Evermore for the festival.[PARAGRAPH:1]"What of these items?" she asked.[PARAGRAPH:1]"The mask is for the festival," Hemah lied, he wore the mask to keep him from seeing his own reflection. That helped keep him from dreaming about himself, which was an exhilarating and terrifying experience.[PARAGRAPH:1]"The feather I found on the edges of your empire. I've only had it for a few days and I'm not sure what to make of it."[PARAGRAPH:1]"It is beautiful." Thessa was more practical than most of the Ljosalfar, and had never seen much value in spiritual or artistic matters but she couldn't deny the draw of the feather. She tested it several times before Hemah came into the room and it was the reason she wanted to question him directly. It wasn't magical, but she couldn't believe the draw it had without magical means.[PARAGRAPH:1]"It's the second most beautiful thing I've seen in your lands."[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah's meaning was obvious from the way he was looking at her, but Thessa pretended to miss the compliment.[PARAGRAPH:1]"And the incense?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"It helps me sleep." Hemah honestly responded, "I have troubling dreams sometimes, but if I burn the incense in the room with me I don't have them."[PARAGRAPH:1]"This is an ancient elven craft, I'm surprised to see anyone with it, especially a human. Did you buy it from someone at the festival?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"No, I met a merchant in Kingsport with it. But I don't know how he got it."[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah paused before continuing.[PARAGRAPH:1]"About the feather... I'd like you to have it."[PARAGRAPH:1]Thessa looked surprised and suspicious so Hemah continued.[PARAGRAPH:1]"As I said, I found it at the edge of your empire, so if anything it is yours anyway. It is too beautiful to be stuffed into my tunic for months on end."[PARAGRAPH:1]Thessa would never accept a gift from someone being investigated. The fact that he was offering a gift implied his guilt. But she couldn't help feeling that this was different, that this man was lonely and out of place, but not responsible for the disappearance of the statue or disciple Wyren. And she found herself unable to turn down the feather.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Are you sure? This won't affect the investigation at all. You will still likely spend the night in jail."[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah nodded, "I'm sure."[PARAGRAPH:1]Thessa tucked the feather in her dark hair and smiled at him. That vision was forever burned into Hemah's heart and it was all he could do to keep from professing his eternal love for her. Then she leaned across, kissed him gently on the cheek, whispered her thanks and left the room. He was left stunned.[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon was watching the interview. There were only a handful of suspects that seemed out of place. Though he suspected they were all dead ends. But seeing Thessa kiss the pale human caused a turmoil of emotions that he was unable to understand.[PARAGRAPH:1]When she came out of the room they met to discuss the results of the interviews. Thessa didn't know he had seen the kiss but sensed immediately that he was distant. As they went through each of the suspects they easily agreed to hold or release each of them until they came to Hemah.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Do you think he is a mage without magic, a kidnapper without a victim, an attacker without a weapon and a thief without the goods? We found the wagoneer that sold the missing wagon, the man he described doesn't match any of our suspects. What is it you suspect about this one?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon was unaccustomed to being so directly questioned from anyone except Thessa, it was one of the things that he loved about her. She was right, but even without the kiss there was something about Hemah that bothered him. Devon's father was an angel in Sucellus's charge and that divine birthright usually made his instincts correct.[PARAGRAPH:1]Unable to settle the dispute they asked priest Tuathal's opinion. He peeked into the room where Hemah sat quietly and considered him. After a few minutes he simply said, "I agree with Devon, there is something suspicious about the man that warrants more scrutiny. I would have him held until we find out more."[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon gave the order before Thessa could object. Then Tuathal stepped in to cool the stubborn archmage's temper.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I heard that Devon proposed to you at the festival dance last night. I am sorry it took me so long to congratulate your betrothal."[PARAGRAPH:1]Tuathal's tactic worked and Thessa let her argument go in the face of the priest's good wishes.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Yes, it was an amazing night. I couldn't be happier."[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon was also relaxed by the memories of the previous night, "Now we have only to set a day."[PARAGRAPH:1]Thessa smiled, Hemah's plight was forgotten.[PARAGRAPH:1]A few minutes later guards came and told Hemah he was to be held for further questioning. They led him to a cell where he was locked up with a few pickpockets and a handful of others that were suspected of having something to do with the theft. He went peacefully to the cell, and only argued that he needed his incense so he could sleep. They refused to give it to him and ignored his requests.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah stayed up for most of the night but as the hours went by he found himself drifting off in short bursts. The sleep from the incense wasn't that restful so it had been weeks since he had really slept. In his short bursts of dreams he saw visions of Thessa, the satyr statue, the golden feather as part of the wings of an ancient god, and that god's attack on this very forest. Visions of withered trees and disease.[PARAGRAPH:1]He shook himself awake. These dreams were horrible but he was so tired that he was falling asleep even as he paced back and forth. Eventually the dreams won.[PARAGRAPH:1]When he awoke the barracks was full of concerned guards, mages and priests. Devon was organizing the efforts and getting reports from scouts checking in from various edges of the forest. After a few hours the guards remembered the travelers they had detained and, seeing no opportunity to pursue the investigation and little hope of finding anything if they did, opened the cell and let them go.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah had his mask, incense and other items returned and he was released onto the streets of Evermore. Devon excused himself from his meeting and caught up with Hemah as he walked away from the barracks.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You, where are you going?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah couldn't believe he was going to go through this again.[PARAGRAPH:1]"The guards released me, they said the investigation was suspended."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I know," Devon responded. "I mean you will be leaving Evermore. You will be leaving our forest. You won't return."[PARAGRAPH:1]The captain looked angry and Hemah noticed that the other suspects that had been released weren't given the same speech.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I was hoping to talk to the woman who questioned me before I left. Do you know where she is?"[PARAGRAPH:1]The captain's eyes narrowed, Hemah had found the point of the captain's anger at him and immediately regretted asking the question.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Her name is Thessa, and she is betrothed to me. You will not talk to her."[PARAGRAPH:1]At that Devon called a guard over and ordered him to escort Hemah to the edge of the forest. The guard agreed and with a final glare from Devon Hemah was led away from the barracks.[PARAGRAPH:1]As Hemah walked beside the guard he put on his mask. He was an amazing caster and could cast minor spells simply from sheer strength of will. Especially after the prior night's sleep, he felt more rested than he had in months. As he walked he reached out to the guard's mind. He would travel out to the forests edge alone, all the while believing Hemah walked beside him and left without any problems.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the spell was firmly in place Hemah cut down an alleyway and headed to the mage guild of the city, where he guessed Thessa would be searching for a cause of the corruption that occurred last night.[PARAGRAPH:1]There were three ways to become invisible. Bend light around your body, create an illusion on your body of the surface behind it or simply trick the mind of the person looking at you so that they don't think they see you. It was this last form that Hemah used as he walked into the mage guild. He scanned ahead, finding elves and blocking their mind to his presence. Technically everyone he walked by saw him as he wandered through the hallways and studies of the guild, but they didn't realize it.[PARAGRAPH:1]He didn't try to include Thessa in the spell. She was looking through piles of ancient tomes when he entered the room. She still had the golden feather in her hair.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thessa."[PARAGRAPH:1]She didn't recognize the voice and it took her a second to match the mask with the one she examined the day before. He had a commanding presence and she could feel the magic radiating from him. This figure was much different than the lonely young man she interviewed and a quick touch of her ring warned Devon that she was in danger.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Hemah? What are you doing here?"[PARAGRAPH:1]She reached out and felt the magic flowing through the room, mentally preparing to defend herself against a mental or physical assault. Without thinking she pushed the tomes aside to keep them from getting damaged.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I came for you, this blight consumes hope. It will destroy you or Evermore. You must get out of here."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Did you create it?" What she had seen of the corruption growing in the forest was beyond anything she had seen before. She sensed a lot of power in Hemah, but the corruption was something greater.[PARAGRAPH:1]"No," Hemah replied. "You did. It's a memory of an affliction that struck the forest long ago. It was eventually stopped by an angel, but no such angel exists to stop it now. Come with me."[PARAGRAPH:1]"How do you know about the source of the corruption?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah could feel her gathering power. She was planning to attack him but she wanted to see what she could learn from him first.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Thessa, I don't know the answer to that, things are revealed to me in dreams. Like I know that if you come with me we will be safe."[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon burst through the study door with sword in hand, followed by mages loudly claiming there was nothing threatening the guild. Devon raced across the room, yelling for Thessa to get back but she didn't listen. Instead she channeled a pulse of arcane energy into the room to disrupt any defensive spells Hemah may have active. The mages stopped in alarm as Hemah's invisibility spell dropped and the masked figure popped into view.[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon ducked under Hemah's arm and sliced up along his ribs. Hemah screamed in pain and visions of a sleeping god danced briefly in front of his eyes, in a distant place that god stirred. Thessa prepared another spell as Hemah fell to the floor.[PARAGRAPH:1]Looking up Hemah only said, "Forget," and the impact of the word on the room was dramatic and sudden. It was as if Hemah had never been there.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Why did you set off your ring?" Devon asked in exasperation.[PARAGRAPH:1]Thessa stood confused, the mages behind Devon continued their objections to his rush into the guild and their claims that there wasn't any danger here.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I don't know," she answered, "I'm sorry it was an accident."[PARAGRAPH:1]Devon took a deep breath and sheathed his sword. After a few minutes of apologizing to the mages they finally left him alone with Thessa. She pulled a golden feather out of her hair and stared at it in confusion.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Are you okay?" Devon asked.[PARAGRAPH:1]He sat down and wrapped his arms around her, kissing her lightly on the cheek. She relaxed in his arms.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Did you find anything?"[PARAGRAPH:1]"No," Thessa answered, "not yet."[PARAGRAPH:1]"Have you decided on a day for our wedding yet?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Thessa smiled, she wasn't accustomed to pushing off decisions. But she hadn't been able to pick a day yet.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Soon, I promise."[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah watched Thessa and Devon leave the mage guild late that night. Devon held her as they walked and despite the corruption approaching the city they were enjoying the time they had together. Hemah dumped his incense onto the street, he was no longer afraid of the dreams.[PARAGRAPH:1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE][LINK=LEADER_THESSA]Chapter 5: Beltane Cycle[\LINK]
TEXT.French: [LINK=UNIT_FAWN]Cycle Beltane: Chapitre 1[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=UNIT_SATYR]Cycle Beltane: Chapitre 2[\LINK][NEWLINE][LINK=BUILDING_MONUMENT]Cycle Beltane: Chapitre 3[\LINK][NEWLINE]Cycle Beltane: Chapitre 4[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Although it wasn't uncommon for disciples to miss the evening bell during Beltane, and not unheard of to still be missing the next morning, it was out of character for the bookish disciple Wyren. He had been the least interested in the festival and outside of his religious obligations hadn't attended many of the games or displays that crowded the elven capital.[PARAGRAPH:1]Priest Tuathal watched the flowerbed in concern. The flowers that each bloomed during different parts of the day, arrayed in an arc in order as they bloomed. Numbers marked each section and allowed the flowerbed to function as a large living clock as it was easy to tell the time by looking at the flowers that were in bloom. It was nearly noon and Wyren was still missing.[PARAGRAPH:1]A squirrel chattered loudly above the priest, hoping he may have some treats. Tuathal scowled back, unhappy to see the animal expecting to be fed rather than gathering the food from the forest himself. But the squirrel wouldn't give up and followed the priest from tree to tree as he walked into the grove between the three temples.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tuathal quietly prayed for some guidance. He couldn't help but feel that something bad had happened to Wyren even if everything else seemed normal. Unhappy at being ignored the squirrel climbed out on the branch closest to Tuathal and then jumped from there onto the satyr statue at the center of the grove. But instead of landing gracefully on the satyr's broad arm the squirrel passed completely through the statue and landed with a confused thud on the ground.[PARAGRAPH:1]Tuathal stared in surprise at the squirrel and the statue he had just jumped through. Pulling an acorn from his pocket he scooped the squirrel up onto his shoulder and gave him the nut while studying the statue. The squirrel studied it suspiciously as well.[PARAGRAPH:1]Slowly reaching out Tuathal's hand passed effortlessly through the statue; it was only an illusion. In his short bursts of dreams he saw visions of Thessa, the satyr statue, the golden feather as part of the wings of an ancient god, and that god's attack on this very forest. Visions of withered trees and disease.[PARAGRAPH:1]He shook himself awake. These dreams were horrible but he was so tired that he was falling asleep even as he paced back and forth. Eventually the dreams won.[PARAGRAPH:1]When he awoke the barracks was full of concerned guards, mages and priests. Devon was organizing the efforts and getting reports from scouts checking in from various edges of the forest. After a few hours the guards remembered the travelers they had detained and, seeing no opportunity to pursue the investigation and little hope of finding anything if they did, opened the cell and let them go.[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah had his mask, incense and other items returned and he was released onto the streets of Evermore. Devon excused himself from his meeting and caught up with Hemah as he walked away from the barracks.[PARAGRAPH:1]"You, where are you going?"[PARAGRAPH:1]Hemah couldn't believe he was going to go through this again.[PARAGRAPH:1]"The guards released me, they said the investigation was suspended."[PARAGRAPH:1]"I know," Devon responded. "I mean you will be leaving Evermore. You will be leaving our forest. You won't return."[PARAGRAPH:1]The captain looked angry and Hemah noticed that the other suspects that had been released weren't given the same speech.[PARAGRAPH:1]"I was hoping to talk to the woman who questioned me before I left. Do you know where she is?"[PARAGRAPH:1]The captain's eyes narrowed, Hemah had found the point of the captain's anger at him and immediately regretted asking the question.[PARAGRAPH:1]"Her name is Thessa, and she is betrothed to me. You will not talk to her."[PARAGRAPH:1]At that Devon called a guard over and ordered him to escort Hemah to the edge of the forest. The guard agreed and with a final glare from Devon Hemah was led away from the barracks.[PARAGRAPH:1]As Hemah walked beside the guard he put on his mask. He was an amazing caster and could cast minor spells simply from sheer strength of will. Especially after the prior night's sleep, he felt more rested than he had in months. As he walked he reached out to the guard's mind. He would travel out to the forests edge alone, all the while believing Hemah walked beside him and left without any problems.[PARAGRAPH:1]After the spell was firmly in place Hemah cut down an alleyway and headed to the mage guild of the city, where he guessed Thessa would be searching for a cause of the corruption that occurred last night.[PARAGRAPH:1]There were three ways to become invisible. Bend light around your body, create an illusion on your body of the surface behind it or simply trick the mind of the person looking at you so that they don't think they see you. It was this last form that Hemah used as he walked into the mage guild. He scanned ahead, finding elves and blocking their mind to his presence. Technically everyone he walked by saw him as he wandered through the hallways and studies of the guild, but they didn't realize it.[PARAGRAPH:1]He didn't try to include Thessa in the spell. She was looking through piles of ancient tomes when he entered the room.
